revision.text:
{{COI|date=January 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox writer | name = Julia Frankau | image =Julia Frankau 001.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | pseudonym = Frank Danby | birth_name = Julia Davis | birth_date = {{birth date|1859|7|30|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Dublin]], [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1916|3|17|1859|7|30|df=y}} | death_place = London, England | occupation = Writer | nationality = British | genre = Novels | subject = Jewish life in London | relatives = [[Owen Hall]], [[Eliza Davis]], Harrie Davis | spouse = [[Arthur Frankau]] | children = [[Gilbert Frankau]], [[Ronald Frankau]], Jack Frankau, [[Joan Frankau]] }} '''Julia Frankau''', née '''Julia Davis''' (30 July 1859 – 17 March 1916)<ref name='xs4all'>{{cite web|url=http://www.xs4all.nl/~androom/biography/p016396.htm |title=Frankau, Julia |accessdate=17 October 2008 |date=1 September 2006 }}</ref> was a successful novelist who wrote under the name '''Frank Danby'''. Her first novel was published in 1887: ''Dr. Phillips: A Maida Vale Idyll''. Its portrayal of London Jews and Jewish life, and its discussion of euthanasia by a doctor were controversial. This was followed by more Frank Danby novels and by books on other subjects, including engraving, which were sometimes written under her own name. Frankau continued to write until the time of her death.
==Biography== Frankau's father was Hyman Davis (1824–1875), a London [[Portrait photography|portrait photographer]], though she and her older siblings were born in [[Dublin]], where Davis practised as a [[dentist]] during the 1850s. On returning to London in the early 1860s, the Davis family lived first in [[Mayfair|Bruton Street]] before moving to [[Maida Vale]].<ref>[[Todd Endelman|Todd M. Endelman]], "The Frankaus of London: A Study in Radical Assimilation, 1837-1967", ''Jewish History'' Vol. 8 Nos 1-2, 1994 p127</ref>
She was a sister of the [[Libretto|librettist]] [[Owen Hall]] (1853–1907) and the [[gossip columnist]] and [[Fashion journalism|fashion writer]] [[Eliza Davis|Mrs Aria]] (1861–1931). For a brief period during her early teens, she was home-tutored by [[Laura Marx|Laura Lafargue]], a daughter of [[Karl Marx]].<ref>Mrs Aria, ''My Sentimental Self'', [[Chapman & Hall]] 1922 pp10-11</ref><ref>Todd M. Endelman, "The Frankaus of London: A Study in Radical Assimilation, 1837-1967", ''Jewish History'' Vol. 8 Nos 1-2, 1994, pp. 127-128</ref> Another of her brothers, Harrie Davis, emigrated to [[New York City|New York]], where he was employed as manager of the [[Gettysburg Cyclorama]] and also went on to pursue a journalistic career.<ref>[[Brooklyn Eagle|''Brooklyn Daily Eagle'']] 22 March 1887 p. 1, "A Smokestack Falls"</ref><ref>''[[New-York Tribune]]'' 15 January 1920 p. 6, "Harrie Davis, Writer, Dead"</ref><ref>"Frankau, Julia", at http://androom.home.xs4all.nl/biography/p016396.htm, accessed 16 January 2013</ref>
She married the London cigar importer [[Arthur Frankau]] (1849–1904) in 1883.<ref>Todd M. Endelman, "The Frankaus of London: A Study in Radical Assimilation, 1837-1967", ''Jewish History'' Vol. 8 Nos 1-2, 1994 p. 126</ref> They lived first at 103 Gloucester Terrace ([[W postcode area|London W]]), moving to 32a Weymouth Street in the later 1880s.<ref>Gilbert Frankau, ''Self-Portrait'', Hutchinson 1940 p15</ref> Two of their three sons were author [[Gilbert Frankau]] (1884–1952) and actor [[Ronald Frankau]] (1894–1951) (thus Julia Frankau is grandmother of novelist [[Pamela Frankau]] and actress [[Rosemary Frankau]], and great-grandmother of bibliographer [[Timothy d'Arch Smith]] and scriptwriter [[Sam Bain]]), and their daughter was the [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]] [[University don|don]] [[Joan Bennett (literary scholar)|Joan Bennett]] (1896–1986), one of the "constellation of critics" called by the [[Defense (legal)|defence]] in the [[R v Penguin Books Ltd.|Lady Chatterley Trial]].<ref>Michael Squires (ed.), ''Lady Chatterley's Lover'' and "À Propos of ''Lady Chatterley's Lover''", Cambridge University Press 1993, Introduction pp''xxxviii-xxxix''</ref> In this connection, Julia herself was credited by [[Marie Adelaide Belloc Lowndes|Mrs Belloc Lowndes]] with having been "one of the very few to recognise the genius of [[D. H. Lawrence]]".<ref>Mrs Belloc Lowndes, ''The Merry Wives of Westminster'', Macmillan, 1946, p. 62</ref>
Julia's sister Florette married architect [[Marcus Evelyn Collins|Marcus E. Collins]] in 1889, thus connecting the Davis and Frankau families with [[Arthur Collins (theatre manager)|Arthur Collins]] of [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane|Drury Lane Theatre]], theatrical manager Horace Collins, and stage director Frank Collins.<ref>Horace Collins, ''My Best Riches'', Eyre & Spottiswoode 1941 p. 11</ref> Florette Collins published one novel in 1906, whereupon her sisters suggested she should content herself with being "the beauty of the family".<ref>Mrs Aria, ''My Sentimental Self'', [[Chapman & Hall]] 1922 p. 7</ref><ref>Florence Collins, ''The Luddingtons: A Novel'', Heinemann 1906</ref> The actor [[Henry Irving]] joined Arthur and Julia Frankau's family circle after Mrs Aria became his mistress in the 1890s.<ref>Gilbert Frankau, ''Self-Portrait'', Hutchinson 1940 pp33-34</ref><ref>[[Jeffrey Richards]], ''Sir Henry Irving: A Victorian Actor and his World'', Hambledon & London 2005 pp. 41, 158</ref>
During the 1890s, Julia Frankau began to research and write on [[engraving]], ultimately publishing (under her own married name) three books on the subject. Her sister Eliza recalled: "having started a small collection of eighteenth-century engravings of [[mezzotint]] and [[stipple]], she particularly favoured the English stipple colour prints, and because no book existed telling her what she wanted to know about them, she set to work and wrote one."<ref name="Mrs Aria p. 56">Mrs Aria, ''My Sentimental Self'', Chapman & Hall 1922 p. 56</ref> After she returned to fiction – or, to use her own phrase, "relapsed into novel writing"<ref name=DNB>[http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/55572 "Frankau, Julia (1859–1916)"]. ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2004, accessed 26 July 2011</ref> – in 1902, ''[[The Sketch]]'' found "something quaint in the thought that Mrs Frankau – who, as 'Frank Danby', has recently published that brilliant study of contemporary manners (and morals), ''Pigs in Clover'' – should be, as she is without question, the greatest living authority on that daintiest product of the eighteenth century, the colour-print."<ref>''The Sketch'', 23 September 1903, p. 348</ref>
The commercial success of ''Pigs in Clover'', which coincided with a substantial inheritance from Arthur's late brother and business partner Edwin Frankau (1854–1903), permitted Arthur and Julia Frankau to move from [[Weymouth Street]] to 11 [[Piccadilly|Clarges Street]], as well as acquiring a seaside retreat named Clover Cottage (now 13 South Cliff, [[Eastbourne]]). Their Clarges Street house was said to have been occupied at one time by [[Emma, Lady Hamilton]], thus providing inspiration for Frank Danby's ''Story of Emma, Lady Hamilton''.<ref>Gilbert Frankau, ''Self-Portrait'', Hutchinson 1940 pp76-77</ref><ref name="Mrs Belloc Lowndes p. 57">Mrs Belloc Lowndes, ''The Merry Wives of Westminster'', Macmillan, 1946 p. 57</ref>
== Dr Phillips == The first Frank Danby novel, originally published by [[Henry Vizetelly|Vizetelly]] in 1887, was a somewhat controversial social satire set in the affluent [[Jews|Jewish]] Maida Vale world where the author herself – "a Jewish girl from an [[British Jews|Anglo-Jewish]] family of impeccable [[Orthodox Judaism|orthodoxy]]"<ref>Aryeh Newman, "From Exile to Exit: The Frankau Jewish Connection", [[Jewish Quarterly|''The Jewish Quarterly'']] Vol. 34, No. 4 (128) ,1987, p. 50</ref> – had grown up. [[Punch (magazine)|''Punch'']] was said to have commented: "It should never have been written. Having been written, it should never have been published. Having been published, it should not be read."<ref name="Mrs Belloc Lowndes p. 57"/><ref>Gilbert Frankau, ''Self-Portrait'', Hutchinson 1940 p. 23</ref>
''Dr Phillips'' earned notoriety on two counts. "The Jews in Frankau's novel are repugnant. They are almost without exception uneducated, narrow, clannish, vulgar, materialistic, and tasteless."<ref>Todd M. Endelman, "The Frankaus of London: A Study in Radical Assimilation, 1837-1967", ''Jewish History'' Vol. 8 Nos 1-2, 1994 p. 129</ref> "Imagine the shock," recalled Horace Collins, "when it was discovered that the book contained characters with obvious likenesses to members of the family and cronies of my mother. Their idiosyncrasies and weaknesses had been held up to ridicule with mordant wit and subtle irony. ... ''Dr Phillips'' was, in fact, in advance of the times and might be deemed to have been the precursor of the smart Society type of novel."<ref>Horace Collins, ''My Best Riches'', Eyre & Spottiswoode 1941 p. 34</ref>
The second controversial aspect was the conduct of the eponymous doctor, who deliberately administers a lethal [[morphine|morphia]] overdose to his (German-Jewish) wife in the hope of being able to marry his ([[Gentile]]) mistress, the mother of his illegitimate daughter.<ref>Frank Danby, ''Dr Phillips: A Maida Vale Idyll'', Vizetelly 1887 Bk. III, Ch. ''III-VIII''</ref> It was bruited at the time of publication that the fictional Jewish Dr Phillips (named Dr Abrams in a pre-publication draft) was based on the real-life (Jewish) surgeon [[Ernest Abraham Hart]], then editor of the ''[[British Medical Journal]]'', whose first wife had died by "accidental poisoning" in 1861.<ref>Stephen Lock, Introduction to the limited-edition [[British Medical Association|BMA]] reprint of ''Dr Phillips: A Maida Vale Idyll'', The Keynes Press 1989 pp. ''v-xii''</ref> Mrs Aria insisted that ''Dr Phillips'' had "fluttered the dovecotes of Maida Vale, rattled the skeletons in the cupboards and the stout ladies at the card-tables, but never merited the popular suspicion that the hero was taken from life."<ref name="Mrs Aria p. 56"/> On the other hand, Mrs Belloc Lowndes suggested that the characters in ''Dr Phillips'' had been more closely based on real-life individuals than those of any other Frank Danby novel, recalling particularly that the character of Dr Phillips "was supposed to have been drawn from a well-known doctor, and he must have felt the cap fitted his head, for he bought up and destroyed every copy he was able to procure."<ref name="Mrs Belloc Lowndes p. 57"/>
"The scandal of ''Dr Phillips'' was compounded by publication the following year of [[Amy Levy]]'s ''Reuben Sachs'' (1888). Levy was almost as harsh in her delineation of Jewish manners and morals, and the two works became linked in public discussion, the notoriety of each reinforcing that of the other."<ref>Todd M. Endelman, "The Frankaus of London: A Study in Radical Assimilation, 1837-1967", ''Jewish History'' Vol. 8 Nos 1-2, 1994 p. 132</ref>
== Later novels == Mrs Aria commented that ''The Sphinx's Lawyer'' was "written to defend the undefendable [[Oscar Wilde]]" – she and Frank Danby having both, through their brother Owen Hall, met Wilde in their youth.<ref>Mrs Aria, ''My Sentimental Self'', Chapman & Hall 1922 pp. 15, 54</ref> It is probably not accidental that "Sphinx" was Wilde's name for their mutual friend and fellow-writer [[Ada Leverson]]. ''The Sphinx's Lawyer'' was dedicated to Owen Hall who, according to its author, vehemently disapproved both the story and its subject matter. The printed dedication, addressed directly to her brother, fills a page and a half, insisting: "your harsh criticism has intensified my conviction of the righteousness of the cause I plead ... I have heard all your argument; I know where I stand. It is at the foot of the Throne of Mercy, with my client by my side, the client of the Sphinx's Lawyer. You, as well as I, know what he was in his brilliant youth, you, as well as I, know how weak he was in his strength, of what flawed physique and untoward inheritance. ''Pity'' was the one unsounded note in the chorus of execration that followed this poor leper to his grave, and beyond it; to awaken pity I have written."<ref>Frank Danby, Dedication "To My Brother, 'Owen Hall'", ''The Sphinx's Lawyer'', Heinemann, 1906</ref>
''The Heart of a Child'' (1908), a less controversial tale based on a [[Plot (narrative)|storyline]] devised by Owen Hall, enjoyed great commercial success as a novel, was twice filmed as a [[Film|motion picture]], and rewritten in 1920 by Gilbert Frankau as a [[Play (theatre)|stage play]] – in which form it did not succeed, though Frankau noted that the novel itself was still earning royalties in the Summer of 1939. The heroine Sally Snape was played by [[Edna Flugrath]] in the first film version, [[Alla Nazimova]] in the second, and [[Renee Kelly|Renée Kelly]] in Gilbert Frankau's theatrical adaptation.<ref>Gilbert Frankau, ''Self-Portrait'', Hutchinson 1940 pp215-239</ref><ref>Mrs Aria, ''My Sentimental Self'', Chapman & Hall, 1922, p. 69</ref><ref>1915 movie https://uk.imdb.com/title/tt0006772/, 1920 movie https://uk.imdb.com/title/tt0011270/, imdb accessed 14 January 2013</ref> Her most popular novel was ''Joseph in Jeopardy'' (1912).<ref name=DNB/>
''Twilight'' was a novel completed by Frank Danby on her deathbed,<ref>Mrs Aria, ''My Sentimental Self'', Chapman & Hall 1922 p. 8</ref> about a female author on her deathbed who is inspired to write about the death of a female author. The character of the ailing Jane Vevaseur is a semi-autobiographical portrayal of Julia Frankau, while her loving sister Eliza Aria is represented by the character of Ella Lovegrove.<ref name=DNB/> The title itself is a doubly resonant [[Word play|play on words]] – the [[Adage|dictum]] "Work whilst ye have the light" is quoted several times by the narrator, alluding to the fact that she (like Frank Danby) is running out of time;<ref>Frank Danby, ''Twilight'', Dodd, Mead & Co. 1916 pp. 4,16 ''et seqq.''</ref> and it transpires that Dr Kennedy, Jane Vevaseur's medical attendant, brought about the death of writer Margaret Capel some years previously by deliberately administering a lethal overdose of what the narrator refers to as [[Twilight sleep|"hyoscine"]], a drug known in its day as "Twilight Sleep". Unlike the undetected murder in ''Dr Phillips'', however, this one is conducted with great reluctance at the patient's own poignant request.<ref>Frank Danby, ''Twilight'', Dodd, Mead & Co. 1916 pp2. 50, 341-356</ref>
== Works == * Essays in the ''Saturday Review'' * ''Dr. Phillips: A Maida Vale Idyll'' (1887) * ''A Babe in Bohemia'' (1889) * ''The Copper Crash'' (1889) * A chapter of ''[[The Fate of Fenella]]'' (1891/92), an experiment in consecutive novel writing * ''Eighteenth Century Colour Prints: An Essay on Certain Stipple Engravers & Their Work in Colour'' (1900) - published in her real name * ''[[John Raphael Smith]] 1752-1812: His Life and Works'' (1902) - published in her real name * ''Pigs in Clover'' (1903) * ''Eighteenth Century Artists and Engravers: [[William Ward (engraver)|William Ward]] ARA, [[James Ward (artist)|James Ward]] RA'' (1904) - published in her real name * ''Baccarat'' (1904) * ''The Sphinx's Lawyer'' (1906) * ''A Coquette in Crape'' (1907) * ''The Heart of a Child'' (1908) * ''An Incompleat Etonian'' (1909) * ''Sebastian'' (1909) * ''The Story of [[Emma, Lady Hamilton]]'' (1910) - later reissued as ''Nelson's Legacy'' * ''Let the Roof Fall In'' (1910) * ''Joseph in Jeopardy'' (1912) * ''Full Swing'' (1914) * ''Twilight'' (1916) * ''Mothers and Children'' (1918) - a collection of previously unpublished stories edited by her son [[Gilbert Frankau]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{wikisource|Author:Julia Frankau|Julia Frankau}} * [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9805E3D6103FE233A2575BC1A9659C946796D6CF Death note in the ''New York Times''] * [http://www.npg.org.uk/live/search/portrait.asp?LinkID=mp19496&rNo=0&role=sit Portrait] * [http://www.condenaststore.com/VanityFair/ProdDetail.aspx?prodId=19953 Portrait] * [http://www.londonfictions.com/julia-frankau-a-babe-in-bohemia.html Lisa Robertson's article about 'A Babe in Bohemia' on the London Fictions website] * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Julia Frankau}} * {{Librivox author |id=10882}}

{{Infobox professional wrestler |name=Jumbo Tsuruta |image=Jumbo Tsuruta.jpg |image_size=200px |names=Jumbo Tsuruta
Tommy Tsuruta
The Terror of Yamanashi |height={{height|m=1.97|precision=0}} |weight={{convert|130|kg|lb|abbr=on}} |birth_date={{Birth date|1951|3|25|mf=y}} |birth_place=[[Makioka, Yamanashi]], [[Japan]] |resides= |birth_name = Tomomi Tsuruta |billed= |trainer=[[Dory Funk Jr.]]
[[Lou Thesz]]
[[All Japan Pro Wrestling]] |debut=March 24, 1973 |death_date={{death date and age|2000|5|13|1951|3|25|mf=y}} |death_place=[[Quezon City]], [[Metro Manila]], [[Philippines]] |death_cause=Complications from [[kidney transplant]] |retired=February 20, 1999 }} {{nihongo|'''Tomomi Tsuruta'''|鶴田 友美|Tsuruta Tomomi|extra=March 25, 1951 – May 13, 2000}}, better known by his [[ring name]] {{nihongo|'''Jumbo Tsuruta'''|ジャンボ鶴田|Janbotsuruta}}, was a [[Japan]]ese [[Puroresu|professional wrestler]] who wrestled for [[All Japan Pro Wrestling]] (AJPW) for most of his career, and is well known for being the first ever [[Triple Crown Heavyweight Championship|Triple Crown Heavyweight Champion]], having won the [[PWF Heavyweight Championship]], the [[NWA United National Championship]], and the [[NWA International Heavyweight Championship]], and unifying the three titles. He is also known for being one-half of the first-ever [[World Tag Team Championship (AJPW)|World Tag Team Champions]] with [[Yoshiaki Yatsu]], having won the [[NWA International Tag Team Championship]] and the [[PWF Tag Team Championship]], and [[Championship unification|unifying]] the two titles. == Early life == Tsuruta participated in many [[sport]]s, such as [[swimming (sport)|swimming]], [[basketball]], and [[sumo]] while attending Hikawa Senior High School in Yamanashi-shi, Yamanashi Prefecture. == Amateur wrestling career == While at [[Chuo University]], he began an [[amateur wrestling]] career. He won the All Japan Amateur Wrestling Championship in [[Freestyle wrestling|freestyle]] and [[Greco-Roman wrestling|Greco-Roman]] as a [[superheavyweight]] (at the time, an unlimited class for those weighing over 100 [[kilograms]]) in the years 1971 and 1972. He also competed in the [[1972 Summer Olympics]] in [[Munich]]. He finished the Greco-Roman tournament with no wins. == Professional wrestling career == Scouted by AJPW promoter [[Giant Baba]], he was sent to the local [[Amarillo, Texas]] promotion in the U.S. to train as a pro under [[Dory Funk Jr.]] While wrestling in the United States, Tsuruta was the first Japanese wrestler to be cheered by an American crowd, due to his hard work ethic and wrestling ability. The name "Jumbo" was given to him by a fan contest in Japan to replace his given name, which was seen as too [[Femininity|feminine]]. He defeated Nick Bockwinkel on February 22, 1984 to win the [[AWA World Heavyweight Championship]] in [[Tokyo]], Japan. He would lose the title to Rick Martel on May 13, 1984 in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|St. Paul, Minnesota]]. Tsuruta and [[Yoshiaki Yatsu]] became the first [[World Tag Team Championship (AJPW)|World Tag Team Champions]] on June 10, 1988. During his 26-year career, he fought in 3,329 matches.{{Cite web|url=http://www.geocities.com/smokyrobmoore/jp052200.htm|accessdate=2008-11-03|title=View from the Rising Sun by Masanori Horie--Jumbo Tsuruta-1951-2000|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105063156/http://www.geocities.com/smokyrobmoore/jp052200.htm|archivedate=2008-01-05}} Some of his most notable opponents include [[Stan Hansen]], [[Billy Robinson]], [[Dick Beyer|The Destroyer]], [[Bruiser Brody]], [[Genichiro Tenryu]], [[Abdullah the Butcher]], [[Terry Funk]], [[Dory Funk Jr.]], [[Mitsuharu Misawa]], [[Harley Race]], [[Verne Gagne]], [[Rick Martel]], [[Riki Choshu]], [[Jack Brisco]], [[Ric Flair]], and [[Nick Bockwinkel]]. Tsuruta was the first [[Triple Crown Heavyweight Championship|Triple Crown Heavyweight Champion]] (unifying the Pacific Wrestling Federation, NWA United National, and NWA International Heavyweight titles), defeating Stan Hansen on April 18, 1989 in Tokyo. In 1992, he completed the October "Giant Series" tour before disappearing from the company for almost a year. For the rest of his career, he participated mostly in comedic (i.e. exhibition) six-man tag team matches; he frequently teamed with Baba and old rival [[Rusher Kimura]] in matches against teams which included [[Masanobu Fuchi]], [[Haruka Eigen]], and other old-timers. He announced his retirement on February 20, 1999 and held a ceremony on March 6, 1999. == Post-retirement and death == Four days after Tsuruta's retirement, he and his family moved to the [[United States]] to be a visiting researcher at the [[University of Portland]] in [[Oregon]]. Tsuruta had a bachelor's degree in political science and earned a master's degree in coaching in 1997, later becoming a part-time instructor in physical training at his old University. His health deteriorated, however, as he had been diagnosed with kidney cancer, which eventually spread to his liver, and by the end of the year he was back in Japan. In April 2000, he left for Australia, where he had an operation to remove the cancer, while there a kidney donor was found in Manila. Tsuruta died at the [[National Kidney and Transplant Institute]] in [[Quezon City]], [[Philippines]] on May 13, 2000, from complications of the [[kidney transplant]]. He had three sons: Ken, Naoki, and Yuji. == Championships and accomplishments == * '''[[All Japan Pro Wrestling]]''' ** [[NWA International Heavyweight Championship]] ([[NWA International Heavyweight Championship#Title history|3 times]]) ** [[NWA International Tag Team Championship]] ([[NWA International Tag Team Championship#Title history|9 times]]) – [[Giant Baba]] (6), [[Genichiro Tenryu]] (2), and Yoshiaki Yatsu (1) ** [[NWA United National Championship]] ([[NWA United National Championship#Title history|5 times]]) ** [[PWF World Heavyweight Championship]] ([[PWF World Heavyweight Championship#Title history|1 time]]) ** [[PWF World Tag Team Championship]] ([[PWF World Tag Team Championship#Title history|2 times]]) – [[Mitsuharu Misawa|Tiger Mask II]] (1) and Yoshiaki Yatsu (1) ** [[Triple Crown Heavyweight Championship]] ([[Triple Crown Heavyweight Championship#Title history|3 times]]) ** [[World Tag Team Championship (AJPW)|World Tag Team Championship]] ([[World Tag Team Championship (AJPW)#Title history|7 times]]) – [[Yoshiaki Yatsu]] (5), [[Great Kabuki|The Great Kabuki]] (1), and [[Akira Taue]] (1) ** [[Champion Carnival]] (1980, 1991) ** [[World's Strongest Tag Determination League]] ([[World's Strongest Tag Determination League#1978|1978]], [[World's Strongest Tag Determination League#1980|1980]]) – with Giant Baba ** World's Strongest Tag Determination League ([[World's Strongest Tag Determination League#1984|1984]], [[World's Strongest Tag Determination League#1986|1986]]) – with Genichiro Tenryu ** World's Strongest Tag Determination League ([[World's Strongest Tag Determination League#1987|1987]]) – with [[Yoshiaki Yatsu]] ** January 2 Korakuen Hall Heavyweight Battle Royal (1984){{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/alljapan/miscaj.html#hvywt|title=Misc. All Japan Events|publisher=}} ** Champion Carnival Distinguished Service Award (1977, 1979)https://www.cagematch.net/?id=26&nr=925https://www.cagematch.net/?id=26&nr=927 ** Champion Carnival Technical Award (1978)https://www.cagematch.net/?id=26&nr=926 ** Champion Carnival Technique Award (1976)http://www.purolove.com/ajpw/history/carnival76.php ** Champion Carnival Fighting Spirit Award (1975, 1982)https://www.cagematch.net/?id=26&nr=930http://www.purolove.com/ajpw/history/carnival75.php ** World's Strongest Tag Determination League Distinguished Award (1977) - with Giant Baba ** World's Strongest Tag Determination League Outstanding Performance Award (1982) - with Giant Babahttp://www.purolove.com/ajpw/history/rwtl82.php ** World's Strongest Tag Determination League Technical Award (1983) - with Genichiro Tenryuhttps://www.cagematch.net/?id=26&nr=1532 ** World's Strongest Tag Determination League Distinguished Service Medal Award (1985) - with Genichiro Tenryuhttps://www.cagematch.net/?id=26&nr=1530 ** World's Strongest Tag Determination League Outstanding Performance Award (1988) - with Yoshiaki Yatsuhttp://www.purolove.com/ajpw/history/rwtl88.php ** World's Strongest Tag Determination League Special Award (1989)https://www.cagematch.net/?id=26&nr=1526 ** World's Strongest Tag Determination League Skill Award (1990) - with Akira Tauehttps://www.cagematch.net/?id=26&nr=254 ** World's Strongest Tag Determination League Fighting Spirit Award (1991) - with Akira Tauehttps://www.cagematch.net/?id=26&nr=253 * '''[[American Wrestling Association]]''' ** [[AWA World Heavyweight Championship]] ([[AWA World Heavyweight Championship#Title history|1 time]]) * '''[[Championship Wrestling from Florida]]''' ** [[NWA United National Championship]] ([[NWA United National Championship#Title history|1 time]]) * '''[[NWA Detroit]]''' ** [[NWA World Tag Team Championship (Detroit version)|NWA World Tag Team Championship ''(Detroit version)'']] ([[NWA World Tag Team Championship (Detroit version)#Title history|1 time]]) – with Giant Baba * '''''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]''''' ** PWI ranked him #'''28''' of the 500 best singles wrestlers during the "PWI Years" in 2003 * '''[[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum|Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]]''' ** Class of 2015{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2014/11/26/22096551.html|title=Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame Class of 2015 announced|last=Oliver|first=Greg|date=2014-11-26|accessdate=2014-11-28|work=Slam! Sports|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]}} * '''''[[Tokyo Sports]]''''' ** [[Tokyo Sports Puroresu Awards#MVP Award|Wrestler of the Year]] (1983, 1984, 1991){{cite web|url=http://www.puroresu.com/awards/1980s.html|title=The Great Hisa's Puroresu Dojo: Puroresu Awards: 1980s|work=Puroresu Dojo}}{{cite web|url=http://www.puroresu.com/awards/1990s.html|title=The revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox artwork | title = Kiepenkerl – 1953 statue | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist =Albert Mazzotti Jr (re-creating the destroyed 1896 original by August Schmiemann) | year = 1953 | type = [[Bronze]] | height_metric = 175 | height_imperial = 69 | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = Kiepenkerl Square, [[Münster]], [[Germany]] | owner = City of Münster }} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = | painting_alignment = Front | image_size = 200px | title = Kiepenkerl – 1987 statue | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = Jeff Koons | year = 1987 | type = [[Stainless steel]], cast and polished | height_metric = 184.8 | width_metric = 80.0 | length_metric = 81.9 | height_imperial = {{frac|72|3|4}} | width_imperial = {{frac|31|1|2}} | length_imperial = {{frac|32|1|4}} | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States]] | museum = [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]] | owner = [[Smithsonian Institution]] }} '''''Kiepenkerl''''' was originally a sandstone statue of a travelling merchant created by August Schmiemann in [[Münster]], [[Germany]] in 1896. Destroyed in World War II, it was re-created in cast metal by Albert Mazzotti Jr in 1953. The statue now stands in a small square in the Old Quarter of Münster. In 1987 American sculptor [[Jeff Koons]] created a replica of the design in polished cast stainless steel. ==1896 statue== The original statue, like its successors, depicted a kiepenkerl (literally "pannier guy": a travelling merchant or pedlar [US: peddler] with a carrying basket, whistle, knot stick and linen smock. It was carved from [[Westerberg (Baumberge)|Baumberger]] sandstone by August Schmiemann and was inaugurated in [[Münster]] on 16 October 1896. The statue was destroyed by a US tank in [[World War II]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.skulptur-projekte.de/archiv/87/koons/index.htm|title=Skulptur. Projekte in Münster 1977. Jeff Koons.|website=www.skulptur-projekte.de|access-date=2018-01-31}} ==1953 statue== [[File:Muenster Kiepenkerl 5972.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Albert Mazzotti Jr's 1953 re-creation of the 1896 ''Kiepenkerl'' statue by August Schmiemann that was destroyed in World War II]] A competition for a new statue was held immediately after the war ended. However, the new designs were vetoed by the mayor of [[Münster]], [[Karl Zuhorn ]] ([[:de: Karl Zuhorn |de]]). Subsequently Albert Mazzotti Jr was commissioned to create a statue in bronze. It was inaugurated on 20 September 1953 by [[Federal President of Germany|Federal President]] [[Theodor Heuss]]. Its location is Kiepenkerl Square, in the Old Quarter of Münster ({{coord| 51.9641|N|7.6262|E|format=dms}}). ==1987 statue== [[File: Kiepenkerl - Jeff Koons.JPG |thumb|200px|right|The 1987 replica of the ''Kiepenkerl'' statue by [[Jeff Koons]]]] For the 1987 [[Skulptur Projekte Münster|Sculpture Projects Münster]], American sculptor [[Jeff Koons]] created a replica of the statue in polished cast stainless steel. Koons produced an edition of three; one is on display at the [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] ({{coord|38|53.329|N|77|1.380|W |region:US-DC_type:landmark |display=inline,title }}). [http://www.lwl.org/skulptur-projekte-download/muenster/87/koons/p_koo.htm Der Kiepenkerl in Edelstahl, Seite des Landschaftsverbandes Westfalen-Lippe anlässlich der Skulptur.Projekte 1987]{{cite web|url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=130H47049WI14.219&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!22509~!0&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=jeff+koons&index=.AW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1#focus |title=Kiepenkerl, (sculpture) |website=Siris-artinventories.si.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-04-18}}{{cite web|url=http://hirshhorn.si.edu/visit/collection_object.asp?key%3D32%26subkey%3D14713 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100603002118/http://www.hirshhorn.si.edu/visit/collection_object.asp?key=32&subkey=14713 |archivedate=2010-06-03 |df= }} The guide for the Sculpture Projects Münster includes these notes by Georg Jappe:
The Kiepenkerl monument symbolizes the man who comes to town with a few eggs, potatoes, and rabbits in his "Kiepe" (a huge basket carried on the back). Actually he is a "Kötter" (a tenant farmer). The statue, created by an academic sculptor, became especially popular when, during the war, everything was burnt down, only the statue remained standing and then was blasted by a tank crew. The will to survive during the hoarding times: as early as 1953, the city of Münster still in ruins, Theodor Heuss inaugurated a new life-size Kiepenkerl monument in bronze. Bronze is art. That is the only art in this restoration monument. Jeff Koons now has recast it in stainless steel which he calls the "material of the masses" (a highly complicated procedure: as the form does not correspond to any industrial standard, the various parts had to be smelted at 1800 degrees Centigrade and cast one by one and then welded together) and finally gave it a high mirror polish to create a "false front of luxury".
==See also== * [[List of public art in Washington, D.C., Ward 2]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{commons category-inline|Kiepenkerl|''Kiepenkerl''}} *[http://virtualglobetrotting.com/map/kiepenkerl-by-jeff-koons/ Virtual Globe Trotting] *[http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WM7J12_Kiepenkerl_Washington_DC Waymarking] *{{cite web|url=http://www.flickriver.com/photos/wallyg/3623254057/ |title=Washington DC - Hirshorn Museum and Sculpture Garden - ''Kiepenkerl'' by Jeff Koons - a photo on Flickriver |website=Flickriver.com |date=2009-06-06 |accessdate=2017-04-18}} {{Jeff Koons}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kiepenkerl}} [[Category:1987 sculptures]] [[Category:Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Sculptures by Jeff Koons]] [[Category:Sculptures of the Smithsonian Institution]] [[Category:Steel sculptures in Washington, D.C.]] {{Public-art-stub}}

page.title: List of films shot at the British Museum

revision.comment: sp
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} [[File:British Museum reading room.jpg|thumb|The Reading Room in the British Museum as it appeared in 2004. Used in many films as a backdrop including Hitchcock's ''Blackmail'' and Zinnemann's ''The Day of the Jackal''.]] The following is a '''list of films featuring the [[British Museum]]''' in the plot line, and/or with scenes filmed there ordered by release date:
''[[The Wakefield Case]]'' (1921) :Four rubies belonging to the British Museum are stolen. A man called Wakefield is killed after trying to capture two brothers in possession of the jewels. His son (Wakefield Jr), a playwright, investigates and follows a woman whom he suspects of his father’s murder across the Atlantic to the US. Wakefield eventually solves the case and falls in love with the woman, who was in fact a Secret Service agent working under cover as a member of the gang.<ref>[http://www.afi.com/members/catalog/DetailView.aspx?s=1&Movie=13055 AFI Catalog: Feature Films] ''The Wakefield Case''</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title.jsp?stid=505144 |title=The Wakefield Case (1921) |publisher=Tcm.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-02}}</ref>
''[[Blackmail (1929 film)|Blackmail]]'' (1929) :''Blackmail'' features a chase scene around the British Museum, although due to low light inside the building, the director [[Alfred Hitchcock]] made do with blown-up photographs as studio backdrops. The last shot of the film is the dome of the [[British Museum Reading Room|Reading Room]].<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0019702/locations IMDb] ''Blackmail''</ref><ref name=Cohen2005>{{citation | last=Cohen | first=Tom | year=2005 | title=Hitchcock's cryptonymies, Volumes 1-2 | publisher=U of Minnesota Press | isbn=978-0-8166-4206-9 | page=76}}</ref>
''[[Bulldog Jack]]'' (1935) :A comedy thriller which ends in a chase through a secret (fictitious) tunnel from ‘Bloomsbury’ underground station (clearly modelled on the [[British Museum tube station|British Museum underground station]] which closed in September 1933, not long before this film was made) to the Egyptian room at the Museum. The film features the British Museum in the story line, but was filmed at Shepherd's Bush Studios.<ref name=Reid2006>{{citation | last=Reid | first=John Howard | year=2006 | title=Success in the Cinema: Money-Making Movies and Critics' Choices | isbn=978-1-84728-088-6 | page=90}}</ref>
'' [[Night of the Demon]]'' (1957) : John Holden ([[Dana Andrews]]) is seen researching in the British Museum reading room about the origin of an ancient but once powerful Satanic cult.
'' [[Phaedra (film)|Phaedra]]'' (1962) :Jules Dassin's 1962 film ''Phaedra'' was an updated version of [[Euripides]]' ''[[Hippolytus (play)|Hippolytus]]''. [[Melina Mercouri]] plays the eponymous [[tragic heroine]] who falls in love with her stepson, Alexis/Hippolytus, played by [[Anthony Perkins]]. In the film, Phaedra meets her stepson for the first time in the British Museum's Duveen Gallery where the [[Parthenon Marbles|Parthenon sculptures]] are displayed.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0056346/ IMDb] ''Phaedra''</ref>{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}}
''[[The Ipcress File (film)|The Ipcress File]]'' (1965) :An encounter between hero and villain, though using the exterior of the [[Royal School of Mines]] in [[South Kensington]], used as the interior location a library at the British Museum (not the main reading room).<ref name=FrankGreenaway2007>{{citation | author=Frank Greenaway | year=2007 | title=Chymica Acta | publisher=Jeremy Mills Publishing | isbn=978-1-905217-50-2 | page=99}}</ref>
''[[Day of the Jackal]]'' (1973) :The Jackal is seen researching at the British Museum reading room.<ref name=Sinyard2003>{{citation | last=Sinyard | first=Neil | year=2003 | title=Fred Zinnemann: films of character and conscience | publisher=McFarland | isbn=978-0-7864-1711-7 | page=136}}</ref><ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0069947/locations IMDb] ''Day of the Jackal''</ref>
''[[Maurice (film)|Maurice]]'' (1987) :The film is based on the [[Maurice (novel)|novel]] by [[E. M. Forster|E.M. Forster]] (written 1913-, published posthumously 1971). In this scene, Maurice bumps into his old schoolmaster (Simon Callow) by the Assyrian sculptures.<ref name=Black2000>{{citation | last=Black | first=Barbara J. | year=2000 | title=On exhibit: Victorians and their museums | publisher=University of Virginia Press | isbn=978-0-8139-1897-6 | page=119}}</ref>
''[[Tale of the Mummy]]'' (1998)
''[[The Mummy Returns]]'' (2001) :The British Museum is the new home for Imhotep.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0209163/locations IMDb] ''The Mummy Returns''</ref><ref name=Keene2005>{{citation | last=Keene | first=Suzanne | year=2005 | title=Fragments of the world: uses of museum collections | publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann | isbn=978-0-7506-6472-1 | page=109}}</ref> A British Museum curator Baltus Hafez (Alun Armstrong) leads a cult who have resurrected the ancient Egyptian god Imhotep with the intent of using Imhotep's power to defeat the Scorpion King. The cult capture Alex, the eight-year-old son of Rick ([[Brendan Fraser]]) and Evelyn O'Connell ([[Rachel Weisz]]) who set off to save their son and save the world from Imhotep.
''[[Possession (2002 film)|Possession]]'' (2002) :Roland Michell ([[Aaron Eckhart]]) is an American scholar working at the British Museum as a research assistant to Professor Blackadder ([[Tom Hickey (actor)|Tom Hickey]]), an expert on Randolph Henry Ash, a 19th-century English poet. One afternoon while studying Ash's Latin texts in the London Library (sequences filmed in the Arched Room in the British Museum),<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/the_museum/business_services/film_and_radio/arched_room.aspx British Museum] The Arched Room</ref> Roland discovers two drafts of what appear to be love letters written by Ash to the Victorian poet Christabel LaMotte. Roland takes the letters to Maud Bailey ([[Gwyneth Paltrow]]), a gender studies scholar, an expert on LaMotte who also happens to be a distant relation.
''[[Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb]]'' (2014)
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==See also== [[List of films shot at the Palace of Versailles]]
{{British Museum}}
[[Category:Lists of films by shooting location|British Museum]] [[Category:British Museum]] [[Category:London-related lists|Films shot at the British Museum]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Law articles needing an infobox]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
Dating maintenance tags: {{Fact}}
revision.text:
[[Africa]]n countries have been sites for [[clinical trial]]s by large [[Pharmaceutical industry|pharmaceutical companies]], raising human rights concerns.<ref name="Washington p390">Washington, Harriet A. ''[[Medical Apartheid]]'', [[Anchor Books]] 2006 p390</ref> Incidents of unethical experimentation, clinical trials lacking properly [[informed consent]], and forced medical procedures have been claimed and prosecuted.
==Specific incidents by date==
===Meningitis testing in Nigeria: 1990s===
{{Main article|Abdullahi v. Pfizer, Inc.}}
The Pfizer drug [[Trovan]] was used in a clinical trial in [[Kano]], [[Nigeria]]. The trial compared the new antibiotic (Trovan) against the best treatment available at the time (intravenous ceftriaxone). Eleven children died in the trial: five after taking Trovan and six after taking an older antibiotic used for comparison in the clinical trial. Others suffered blindness, deafness and brain damage, the cause of which is difficult to determine because these disabilities are relatively common outcomes of the disease itself. A panel of medical experts later implicated Pfizer in the incident, concluding the drug had been administered as part of an illegal clinical trial without authorization from the Nigerian government or consent from the children's parents. This led to a lawsuit from the Nigerian government over informed consent.<ref name="Washington p392-393">Washington, Harriet A. ''[[Medical Apartheid]]'', Anchor Books 2006 p392-393</ref><ref name="news.bbc.co.uk">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6719141.stm |title=Africa | Nigeria sues drugs giant Pfizer |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=2007-06-05 |accessdate=2010-11-12}}</ref> Pfizer countered that it met all the necessary regulations.<ref name="Washington p392-393"/> Note: the drug was then approved for general use in the US, and then eventually withdrawn due to [[hepatotoxicity]].
===HIV/AIDS testing in Zimbabwe: 1990s=== [[Zidovudine|AZT]] trials conducted on HIV-positive African subjects by U.S. physicians and the [[University of Zimbabwe]] were not performed with proper informed consent.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The United States began testing AZT treatments in Africa in 1994, through projects funded by [[Centers for Disease Control]] (CDC), World health organization (WHO) and the [[National Institutes of Health]] (NIH). It included testing of over 17,000 women for a medication that prevents mother-to-child transmission of HIV/AIDS. The subjects did not fully understand the testing methods, the effectiveness, the possible dangers, or the nature of a [[placebo]] in testing situations.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> They were also told about the trials under duress.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Half of these women received a placebo that has no effect, making transmission likely. As a result, an estimated 1000 babies contracted HIV/AIDS although a proven life-saving regimen already existed.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The CDC ended the short course testing in 1998 after they announced they had enough information from [[Thailand]] trials.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
===Forced sexual reassignment in South Africa: 1970s–1980s=== In a project headed by Dr. [[Aubrey Levin]] during the 1970s to 1980s, the [[South African Defence Force]] forced lesbian and gay military personnel to undergo "sex-change" operations. This was part of a secret program to purge homosexuality in the army.<ref name="mindpowernews.com">http://www.mindpowernews.com/UnethicalExperiments.htm</ref> It included psychological coercion, chemical castration, electric shock, and other unethical medical experiments. An estimated 900 forced sexual reassignment operations may have been performed between 1971 and 1989 at military hospitals.<ref name="mindpowernews.com"/>Most of the victims were males, young 16 to 24-year-old white men who were drafted into the army during the [[South African Border War]]. Women were also subject to the experimentation.<ref name="mindpowernews.com"/><ref>http://www.mrc.ac.za/healthsystems/aversion.pdf</ref>
===Forced contraception in Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe): 1970s=== [[Depo-Provera]] was clinically tested on black Rhodesian (now Zimbabwean) women in the 1970s.<ref name="Washington p390"/> Once approved, the drug was used as a population control measure. Women on white-run commercial farms were coerced into accepting Depo-Provera.<ref name="Kaler, Amy 1998. p 347">Kaler, Amy. 1998. "A Threat to the Nation and a Threat to the Men: the Banning of Depo-Provera in Zimbabwe, 1981". ''[[Journal of Southern African Studies]]'' 24(2):p 347</ref> In 1981, the drug was banned in what was by then [[Zimbabwe]].<ref name="Kaler, Amy 1998. p 347"/>
===Sterilisation experiments in German South-West Africa (now part of Namibia): Late 1800s–1910s=== Dr. [[Eugen Fischer]] conducted sterilisation experiments on [[Herero people|Herero]] women in [[German South-West Africa]] (now [[Namibia]], less [[Walvis Bay]] etc.) in the early 1900s.<ref name="Washington p390"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ezakwantu.com/Gallery%20Herero%20and%20Namaqua%20Genocide.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111209033514/http://www.ezakwantu.com/Gallery%20Herero%20and%20Namaqua%20Genocide.htm |archivedate=2011-12-09 |df= }}</ref> His experimentation was largely done on mixed-race offspring in order to provide justification to ban [[mixed-race marriage]]s.<ref>[[Eugen Fischer]]</ref> He joined the [[Nazi]] party thereafter where he did similar experiments in the Jewish concentration camps. Late stage studies were later continued by Doctor Hams Harmsen, founder of the German branch of [[International Planned Parenthood Federation]] (IPPF) whose name is also associated with the [[compulsory sterilisation in Nazi Germany]].{{fact|date=November 2018}}
==Effects on legitimate medicine== Unethical medical experimentation that has occurred for over a century may be the cause of the documented fear and mistrust of doctors and medicine in Africa.<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/31/opinion/31washington.html | work=The New York Times | first=Harriet A. | last=Washington | title=Why Africa Fears Western Medicine | date=2007-07-31}}</ref> For example, polio has been on the rise in [[Nigeria]], [[Chad]], and [[Burkina Faso]] because many people there avoid vaccinations because they believe that the vaccines are contaminated with HIV or sterilization agents.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> Due to the meningitis testing incident in Kano, many Nigerians now refuse to participate in clinical trials.<ref name="Washington p392-393"/>
==The role of poverty== Many African nations cannot afford to offer medicine for their citizens without subsidies from multinational pharmaceutical corporations.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> To court these pharmaceutical corporations, some African nations minimize legal regulations on the conduct of medical research, which prevents potential legal battles from arising.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> This forces some Africans to make a [[Hobson's choice]]: "experimental medicine or no medicine at all".<ref>Washington, Harriet A. ''[[Medical Apartheid]]'', Anchor Books 2006 p394</ref> People living in the rural or slum area are also more vulnerable to experimentation because they are more likely to be illiterate and to misunderstand the effects of the experimentation.<ref name="ctj.sagepub.com">{{cite web|url=http://ctj.sagepub.com/content/3/3/306.abstract |title=Problems in comprehension of informed consent in rural and peri-urban Mali, West Africa — Clinical Trials |publisher=Ctj.sagepub.com |date=2006-06-01 |accessdate=2010-11-12}}</ref>
==Codes of ethics== Several national and international bodies have devised codes of ethics for conducting experiments and clinical trials. These include the [[Nuremberg Code]] and [[Helsinki Declaration]]<ref name="ReferenceA">Meier, Benjamin Mason: International Protection of Persons Undergoing Medical Experimentation: Protecting the Right of Informed Consent, ''[[Berkeley Journal of International Law]]'' [1085-5718] Meier yr:2002 vol:20 iss:3 pg:513 -554</ref> and the [[Protocol to the African Charter on Human and Peoples' Rights on the Rights of Women in Africa]], which seeks to prohibit all medical and scientific experiments on women without their prior informed consent.<ref name="allafrica.com">http://allafrica.com/stories/200805290720.html</ref>
==Popular culture references== The book and movie ''[[The Constant Gardener]]'' highlighted the dynamics of conduct in clinical trials in Africa in the slum areas. This was based on the real-life meningitis incident in Kano, Nigeria. [[New York Times best seller]] book ''[[Medical Apartheid]]'' by [[Harriet A. Washington]], provides a historical account of experimentation on [[African Americans]], but also includes the links to African experimentation.<ref name="Washington p392-393"/>
==See also== *[[Human experimentation in North Korea]] *[[Japanese human experimentation]] *[[Nazi human experimentation]] *[[Unethical human experimentation in the United States]] *[[Project Coast]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Medical Experimentation In Africa}} [[Category:Human rights abuses]] [[Category:Human rights in Africa]] [[Category:World Health Organization]] [[Category:Clinical trials]] [[Category:Human subject research]]
